exchangeMarkets.name: New Exchange Markets

keys.name: Key for Lighting Strike

timeMachines.name: Lightning Strike Backtesting Session My Computer
Lightning Strike Live Trading Session My Computer

rootNodes.name: Welcome to Superalgos!
rootNodes.config: { "title": "Congratulations!", "summary": "You are now running Superalgos! Let's get you started! I can't wait to show you around!", "subTitle": "Welcome to Superalgos!", "gif": "", "image": "tutorial", "definition": "I'm an interactive tutorial, the first in a series created to walk you through the basic operation of the system!", "paragraph1": "My goal is to get you started and show you the tools that will help you move around comfortably to discover all the cool things that Superalgos may do for you.", "callOut": "", "paragraph2": "", "note": "", "tip": "Please, always click Next to continue!", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "", "slider": "toTop", "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: That's Me
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "That's Me On the Right!", "gif": "", "image": "tutorial", "definition": "Tutorials are defined within the system, so you may create more of us if you wish! But we'll discuss that God-like power later on... let's focus on the basics first!", "paragraph1": "Superalgos is inherently a visual tool. The system represents information in hierarchical structures of interconnected nodes, represented by icons. What you see on your right is one of these hierarchies—in particular, a ->Tutorial-> hierarchy with a label reading Welcome to Superalgos!", "callOut": "Hover your mouse pointer over the Tutorial node and see what happens!", "paragraph2": "Wow! Cool right? That's a lot of buttons!", "note": "", "tip": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toTop", "positionAtReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Expand That Node!
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Expand That Node!",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "expand",
    "definition": "Each node features a menu. The button on the bottom-left expands and collapses the structure of nodes below the current node.",
    "paragraph1": "",
    "callOut": "Go ahead and click the expand button!",
    "paragraph2": "The ->Tutorial-> node has several offspring, and these have several more offspring. That's why it's a hierarchy!",
    "note": "Structured visual representations of information are at the core of how Superalgos administers the complexity behind flexible and scalable trading operations.",
    "tip": "",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toTop",
 "documentationURL": "" 
}

tutorialSteps.name: Let's Go for a Ride!
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Let's Go for a Ride!",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "network",
    "definition": "Before I show you the rest of the menu, let's take a look at another hierarchy: the ->Network->. ",
    "paragraph1": "The Network hierarchy is the control room of the system. This is where you control your ->Data Mining->, ->Testing Environment->, and ->Production Environment->.",
    "callOut": "Expand the hierarchy and take a look inside!",
    "paragraph2": "See the nodes I mentioned earlier? Cool! We are here to start your first ever data mining operation. Are you ready?",
    "note": "",
    "tip": "",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toTop",
    "pressButton": "",
    "positionAtReferenceParent": true,
 "documentationURL": "" 
}

tutorialSteps.name: Ready to Rock?
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Ready to Rock?",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "data-mining",
    "definition": "The ->Data Mining-> node controls all the data mining tasks defined for this ->Network Node->.",
    "bulletListIntro": "You are about to start the first of the following activities that we'll cover in the next few minutes:",
    "bulletArray": [
        [
            "1. Run a data mining operation",
            " to get data for the BTC/USDT ->Market-> from Binance."
        ],
        [
            "2. Run a ->Backtesting Session->",
            " with an existing open-source strategy."
        ],
        [
            "3. Run a ->Live Trading Session->",
            " with minimal funds, to test the critical aspects of the system."
        ]
    ],
    "paragraph1": "",
    "callOut": "Are you cool with this? Shall we start?",
    "paragraph2": "",
    "note": "",
    "tip": "",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toTop",
    "pressButton": "",
    "positionAtReferenceParent": true,
 "documentationURL": "" 
}

tutorialSteps.name: Let's Mine Some Data!
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "Let's Mine Some Data!", "gif": "", "image": "run", "definition": "The Run All Exchange Data Tasks button on the top-right corner of the menu runs... well... all ->Exchange Data Tasks->!", "paragraph1": "And that is exactly what we want to do, so...", "callOut": "Select the button on the menu and let's mine!", "paragraph2": "Confirm the request by clicking the button a second time. In about 20 seconds, you should see a status notice below the Data Mining node indicating that 1 out of 1 Exchange Data Tasks node is running.", "note": "Your console app should show something similar to the video on the next step.", "tip": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toTop", "pressButton": "", "positionAtReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: GIF
How Are Things Going?
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "How Are Things Going?", "gif": "", "image": "sensor-bot-instance", "definition": "I just dragged you deep into the confines of the Data Mining operation. See the progress of the ->Sensor Bot Instance-> to your right!", "paragraph1": "The sensor bot is currently extracting data from the exchange. As soon as she completes the extraction for the defined datetime range something really cool will happen... automatically!", "callOut": "Can you guess what that may be?", "paragraph2": "I won't tell you! You'll find out soon... be patient! It should take no longer than 3 to 5 minutes to extract the data from Binance. Promise you won't click Next until you see the progress notice at 100%!", "note": "", "tip": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toTop", "pressButton": "", "positionAtReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Candles Volumes in Action
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Candles Volumes in Action",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "indicator-bot-instance",
    "definition": "That's right! Indicators start working as soon as the sensor bot finishes her job!",
    "paragraph1": "You're watching the progress of Candles Volumes. She turns the one-minute candles the sensor bot downloads from the exchange into candles for all time frames.",
    "callOut": "What happens after Candles Volumes finishes?",
    "paragraph2": "Other bots need Candles Volumes to finish her work so that they may start doing theirs. Imagine a bot needs to calculate a 20-periods Simple Moving Average for all time frames. She needs the ->Data Product-> produced by Candles Volumes as input for the SMA calculation. We call such a need a ->Data Dependency->.",
    "note": "",
    "tip": "",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toTop",
    "pressButton": "",
    "positionAtReferenceParent": true,
 "documentationURL": "" 
}

tutorialSteps.name: Click & Drag Baby!
tutorialSteps.config:
{ "subTitle": "Click & Drag Baby!", "gif": "", "image": "hand-drag", "definition": "I want to show you something while the data mining operation progresses. I'll teach you how to walk... in two seconds!", "paragraph1": "", "callOut": "Just click and drag with your mouse!", "paragraph2": "Easy, right? Great!

However, the design space is a huge place and I wouldn't want you to get tendinitis dragging your way around like this. I'll teach you a couple more tricks in the next couple of steps.", "note": "", "tip": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toTop", "pressButton": "", "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Time to Take Control!
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Time to Take Control!",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "key-ctrl",
    "definition": "Yes! You may use your keyboard too! You are going to love this for long-distance travel on the design space!",
    "paragraph1": "Here's the trick:",
    "callOut": "Regular folks may use the <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> key plus arrow keys: <kbd>←</kbd> <kbd>→</kbd> <kbd>↑</kbd> <kbd>↓</kbd>",
    "paragraph2": "",
    "note": "",
    "tip": "Of course Mac fanboys and fangirls must replace <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> with <kbd>Command</kbd>",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toTop",
    "pressButton": "",
 "documentationURL": "" 
}

tutorialSteps.name: Spacetime Teleportation!
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Spacetime Teleportation!",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "mouse-right-click",
    "definition": "Ok, you're not actually going to be teleporting, nor will you bend spacetime, but it almost feels like it! It's time to learn to use the design space map.",
    "paragraph1": "I said earlier that the design space is huge, and I meant it! Going from one corner to the opposite would take hundreds of clicks and drags. While using the keyboard allows you to develop neck-breaking speeds, it's not as cool as teleporting! This is how it works:",
    "callOut": "Right-click to open the map and left-click anywhere on the map to go to that specific spot!",
    "paragraph2": "Look at me on the bottom-left corner of the design space? Now you know where to find me!",
    "note": "",
    "tip": "",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toTop",
    "pressButton": "",
 "documentationURL": "" 
}

tutorialSteps.name: Warp-Speed Zooming!
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Warp-Speed Zooming!",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "mouse-wheel-down",
    "definition": "There's one more tool that you may find useful to manipulate spacetime! The native browser zoom function!",
    "paragraph1": "Sometimes you may wish to visualize larger sections of hierarchies than your screen allows.",
    "callOut": "Hit <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> and scroll the wheel of your mouse!",
    "paragraph2": " ",
    "note": "",
    "tip": "Chrome indicates the level of zoom on the top-right corner. When zooming in or out, the design space gets centered on the screen. After applying the desired level of zoom, use to design space map to go back where you were.",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toTop",
    "pressButton": "",
    "documentationURL": ""
}

tutorialSteps.name: A Bit About Tutorials
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "A Bit About Tutorials...", "gif": "", "image": "tutorial", "definition": "Before we get back to business, let me tell you a few things about how we—tutorials—work.", "bulletListIntro": "This is likely the most important bit:", "bulletArray": [ [ "You are the boss!", " You may stop a tutorial and skip steps—or entire topics—at any point. Once you're ready to pick up the lesson again, find us on the bottom-left corner of the design space. Select Resume on the menu to start where you left, or on the first step skipped. Select Play to start from the beginning!" ] ], "paragraph1": "", "callOut": "Let's try that! Click the Stop button below, and once I'm gone, open my menu and select Resume.", "paragraph2": "", "tip": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toTop", "positionAtReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Need a Quick Reminder?
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "Need a Quick Reminder?", "gif": "", "image": "key-left", "definition": "At this point, I'm probably overflowing your hippocampus! But don't worry... you may go back to any previous step!", "bulletListIntro": "If you ever need a reminder about any of these topics...", "bulletArray": [ [ "Find a ->Tutorial Topic-> and replay it!", " You may find me on the bottom-left corner of the design space, expand me, browse through the hierarchy of topics and steps, and click Play on any of them. Topics are arranged in a clockwise direction, starting from the right-hand side of the main ->Tutorial-> node." ] ], "paragraph1": "", "callOut": "Find the Need a Quick Reminder? step under the Tutorials & Help topic below. Then click Stop, and restart by clicking Play on the said ->Tutorial Step->!", "paragraph2": "", "tip": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toTop", "positionAtReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Hungry For More Info?!
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "Hungry For More Info?", "gif": "", "image": "help", "definition": "I won't go into every detail as we move along, but if you need more info on a node, the help button on the menu takes you straight to its documentation.", "bulletListIntro": "The documentation of a node may include one or more of the following sections:", "bulletArray": [ [ "Definition:", " describes what the node is or does." ], [ "Content:", " describes how the node works." ], [ "Adding:", " describes how to add the node." ], [ "Configure:", " goes through the node's configuration." ], [ "Start:", " for nodes that may be started or stopped." ] ], "paragraph1": "", "callOut": "Click the help button on the ->Data Mining-> node!", "paragraph2": "", "tip": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toTop", "positionAtReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Back to Work!
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Ok... Back to Work!",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "data-mining",
    "definition": "Now that you're comfortable moving around, I want you to go on a little tour exploring the ->Data Mining-> section of the hierarchy.",
    "bulletListIntro": "Notice the following:",
    "bulletArray": [
        [
            "The section is organized—first and foremost—by exchange and market.",
            " This will help you work with multiple exchanges and multiple markets in an orderly fashion."
        ],
        [
            "The ->Exchange Data Tasks-> and ->Market Data Tasks-> nodes",
            " may control all tasks in the exchange and market respectively."
        ]
    ],
    "paragraph1": "",
    "callOut": "Go out and check those nodes and their menus!",
    "paragraph2": "",
    "tip": "",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toTop",
 "documentationURL": "" 
}

tutorialSteps.name: The Magic of Data Mines
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "The Magic of Data Mines",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "data-mine-tasks",
    "definition": "Within each market, the operation is organized by ->Data Mine->. Superalgos ships with several open-source data mines, each with multiple indicators.",
    "paragraph1": "Think of data mines as plugins that developers may create to extend the data analysis capacity of the system. An ->Indicator Bot-> may process data other indicators produce, hence adding value and producing deeper and richer analysis.",
    "callOut": "If you have a basic understanding  of JavaScript, you may create indicators too!",
    "paragraph2": "But I'm getting ahead of myself talking about building data mines at this point! Let's get back on track!",
    "tip": "",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toTop",
    "positionAtReferenceParent": true,
 "documentationURL": "" 
}

tutorialSteps.name: The Core of Data Mining
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "At the Core of Data Mining",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "task",
    "definition": "The core of a data mining operation are tasks running bots. One ->Task-> controls one bot, and a ->Task Manager-> may control multiple tasks.",
    "paragraph1": "Buy now you've learned about six different devices that you may use to control each bot in your data mining operation. At the highest level, the ->Data Mining-> node controls all data mining bots in the ->Network Node->.",
    "callOut": "We'll talk about network nodes in a minute...",
    "paragraph2": "At the lowest level, an individual task controls a single bot. The nodes in between are organizational nodes that help keep the operation orderly, and allow granular control over the different sections.",
    "tip": "",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toTop",
    "positionAtReferenceParent": true,
 "documentationURL": "" 
}

tutorialSteps.name: Are We Up to Date?
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "Are We Up to Date?", "gif": "", "image": "indicator-process-instance", "definition": "By now, all processes should be at 100%. When that happens, we refer to the data mining operation as being up to date.", "paragraph1": "When all processes are up to date, the bots keep running, processing information in realtime as it is produced at the exchange. That is, the data mining operation doesn't stop unless you stop it!", "callOut": "Look around and see if all processes are at 100%", "paragraph2": "To run a ->Live Trading Session->, you need a constant feed of information from the exchange, being processed in realtime, so that the ->Trading Bot-> may apply the rules of your ->Trading System-> to make live trading decisions.", "tip": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toTop", "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Time to Stop!
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "Time to Stop!", "gif": "", "image": "stop", "definition": "We are not going to run a ->Live Trading Session-> just yet, so there is no point in keeping our data mining running at this point.", "bulletListIntro": "There are two main reasons to run a data mining op:", "bulletArray": [ [ "To process historic data.", "You may want to process a datetime range of any given ->Market-> to run a ->Backtesting Session->, or to process new indicators." ], [ "To run a live session.", "Live sessions (->Paper Trading Session->, ->Forward Testing Session->, and ->Live Trading Session->) need a live market feed." ] ], "paragraph1": "", "callOut": "If all processes are up to date, then select Stop All Tasks in the Masters ->Task Manager->", "paragraph2": "", "tip": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toTop", "positionAtReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Careful With Your Data
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Careful With Your Data!",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "dataset-definition",
    "definition": "It may take up to one minute for all tasks to come to a halt. You should never close the system before all tasks stop.",
    "paragraph1": "",
    "callOut": "Take another quick look at the console app to see how tasks get stopped!",
    "paragraph2": "",
    "tip": "",
    "important": "Closing the frontend before tasks stop may cause the tasks to start again the next time you open the frontend.",
    "warning": "Closing the backend before tasks stop may cause your data to become corrupt.",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toTop",
    "positionAtReferenceParent": true,
 "documentationURL": "" 
}

tutorialSteps.name: The Other Dimension
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "The Bright Side",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "charting-space",
    "definition": "So far, you've been confined to the dark side of Superalgos. Get ready to be exposed to the bright side: the ->Charting Space->.",
    "paragraph1": "The charting space lives on top of the design space, separated by a turquoise slider.",
    "callOut": "",
    "paragraph2": "As you will come to expect from Superalgos, the charting space is configurable and highly flexible. Everything that happens there is defined on the ->Charting Space-> hierarchy.",
    "tip": "",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "The charting space is known for blowing people's minds. Please, refrain from continuing with this tutorial if you are currently under the influence of psychoactive substances.",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toMiddle",
    "useReferenceParentTo": "Position at Node",
    "positionAtReferenceParent": true,
 "documentationURL": "" 
}

tutorialSteps.name: Break On Through
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "Break On Through!", "gif": "", "image": "full-board", "definition": "I'll get you up to speed with moving around and browsing the charting space in no time... Let's deal with the slider first!", "paragraph1": "", "callOut": "Click it and drag it down to close the design space and open the charting space. Do the opposite for the reversed effect. To do it with the keyboard, hit Ctrl + Shift + ↓. Try ↑ ← → too!", "paragraph2": "", "note": "Unless you need both spaces to be partially open, it's always a good idea to fully close either of them to save computing resources in your machine.", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Navigating the White Room
tutorialSteps.config:
{ "subTitle": "Navigating the White Room", "gif": "", "image": "mouse-right-click", "definition": "Just like the design space, the charting space features a huge area where you may set up as many charts as you wish... or as many as your hardware can cope with! ", "paragraph1": "There are only two charts in this default ->Workspace->, to keep things simple for newcomers. Advanced users monitor charts from multiple exchanges and multiple markets.", "callOut": "To move around the charting space, click and drag using the right button of the mouse.

The keyboard combination is Shift plus the arrow keys ↑ ← → ↓", "paragraph2": "", "note": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toBottom", "repositionAtTimeMachineNoZoomReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

referenceParent.name: Lightning Strike Backtesting Session My Computer

tutorialSteps.name: Talkin Time Travel
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "Talkin' Time Travel", "gif": "", "image": "time-machine", "definition": "I mentioned earlier there are two charts in this workspace. In Superalgos, we call each of these a ->Time Machine->.", "paragraph1": "A time machine may hold one ->Timeline Chart-> or more. We call them time machines because all timeline charts within a time machine are synchronized in time. This feature of time machines allows to superimpose different layers of data sharing the same ->Time Scale->.", "callOut": "Hover your mouse pointer over the time machines!", "paragraph2": "Notice the label emerging on the left-hand side showing which exchange and market the data is associated with. A single time machine may hold data from multiple markets and multiple exchanges!", "note": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toBottom", "repositionAtTimeMachineNoZoomReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

referenceParent.name: Lightning Strike Backtesting Session My Computer

tutorialSteps.name: Bending Time?
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "Bending time?", "gif": "", "image": "time-machine", "definition": "Ok... maybe it's not actually like bending, but, bear with me... You'll love how you can shape time machines to whatever format you wish.", "paragraph1": "Hover your mouse pointer over any of the edges of the turquoise frame defining the time machine and see what happens. See how the edge is highlighted in yellow?", "callOut": "Cool! Now, left-click the frame and pull!", "paragraph2": "This is how you may shape time machines to your liking. How about shaping the time machine to the exact aspect ratio of your screen? Easy... just point your mouse at the time machine and hit Ctrl + Shift + A", "note": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toBottom", "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Putting Things in Order
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "Putting Things in Order", "gif": "", "image": "hand-drag", "definition": "One more thing before we dive into the charts. You need to know how to put the house in order!", "paragraph1": "The time will come in which you may be working with tens of charts. You already know how to change their format... Now you need to know how to move them around, so that you may create whatever arrangements you require. It's quite easy:", "callOut": "Hit Shift left-click, and drag!", "paragraph2": "I believe we've covered everything about how to manage the charting space. It's time to dive into the charts!", "note": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toBottom", "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Get In the Wormhole!
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Get In the Wormhole!",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "mouse-wheel-up",
    "definition": "It's time to dive into a ->Time Machine-> and see what happens! Are you ready for a full-on immersive experience?",
    "paragraph1": "The charting space is like the Google Maps of market charts. As you already know, you left-click and drag to move around the landscape... but, how do you zoom in to see the details?",
    "callOut": "With the wheel of the mouse! Try it!",
    "paragraph2": "Exactly! Just like in Google Maps! Point the mouse to the area of interest, then roll the wheel of the mouse forwards to zoom in, and backward to zoom out!",
    "note": "",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toBottom",
 "documentationURL": "" 
}

tutorialSteps.name: The Elegant Way...
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "The Elegant Way...", "gif": "", "image": "mouse-pointer", "definition": "I know! Zooming into a random spot is unlikely to position the chart squared with your screen, right? No worries...", "paragraph1": "I'll show you how to get into a chart so that everything fits nicely. First, use the Ctrl + Shift + A keys to adjust the aspect ratio to fit your screen. Then, zoom out fully with your mouse. From this position...", "callOut": "Double-click on the time machine on top! Twice!", "paragraph2": "The first double-click centers the chart, and takes you to a certain level of zoom; some margin is left to fit the name of the chart and the tab on the top-left corner. The second double-click takes you all the way in, to the zoom level on which layer managers emerge.", "note": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toBottom", "keyPressedTimeMachineReferenceParent": { "shiftKey": true, "ctrlKey": true, "metaKey": true, "code": "ArrowRight", "key": "A" }, "repositionAtTimeMachineNoZoomReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

referenceParent.name: Lightning Strike Backtesting Session My Computer

tutorialSteps.name: Moving in Wonderland
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Moving in Wonderland",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "mouse-left-click",
    "definition": "So, you are finally inside a chart. The first thing you'll want to do is move around and learn what these charts may do for you.",
    "paragraph1": "Let's get on with that! Like in the design space—when inside a time machine—you move by using your mouse and your keyboard. This is how: ",
    "callOut": "With the mouse, left-click and drag. With the keyboard, use the arrow keys: <kbd>←</kbd> <kbd>→</kbd> <kbd>↑</kbd> <kbd>↓</kbd>",
    "paragraph2": "",
    "note": "What? It's not working? Are you stuck with a frozen chart? Like in the video on the next step? Don't worry! I know what's going on...",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toBottom",
    "keyPressedTimeMachineReferenceParent": {
        "shiftKey": true,
        "ctrlKey": true,
        "metaKey": true,
        "code": "ArrowRight",
        "key": "A"
    },
    "repositionAtTimeMachineReferenceParent": true,
 "documentationURL": "" 
}

referenceParent.name: Lightning Strike Backtesting Session My Computer

tutorialSteps.name: GIF

referenceParent.name: Lightning Strike Backtesting Session My Computer

tutorialSteps.name: Unlocking Time!
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Unlocking Time!",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "time-scale",
    "definition": "The reason why you can't move is that scales are locked in the automatic mode so that you may easily find the data after your first data mining operation.",
    "paragraph1": "Setting the ->Time Scale-> in automatic mode forces the whole datetime range of available data into the chart.",
    "callOut": "To toggle between the various automatic modes and manual mode, hit <kbd>Shift</kbd> and make a gentle one-step roll with the wheel of your mouse on top of the time scale box.",
    "paragraph2": "Once you've taken care of that, you should be able to move freely on the X-axis, that is, the time axis of the chart. See the video on the next step for clarity.",
    "note": "",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toBottom",
 "documentationURL": "" 
}

tutorialSteps.name: GIF
Scaling Time!

{
    "subTitle": "Scaling Time!",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "time-scale",
    "definition": "Did you pick up the trick to scale time from the previous video? If not, go to the previous step and watch attentively!",
    "paragraph1": "That's it! Scroll it, my friend!",
    "callOut": "Scrolling the wheel of the mouse on top of the time scale box shrinks and expands time!",
    "paragraph2": "",
    "note": "There's one more interesting detail worth noting in the previous video: when the time scale exits the automatic mode, the two tiny green triangles indicating each end of the automatic scale disappear!",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toBottom",
 "documentationURL": "" 
}

tutorialSteps.name: Playing With the Rate Scale!
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Playing with the Rate Scale!",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "rate-scale",
    "definition": "Do I need to tell you how the ->Rate Scale-> works or can you figure it out on your own? Ok... I'll give you a hint...",
    "paragraph1": "",
    "callOut": "The rate scale works like the time scale! Check the video coming next for clarity!",
    "tip": "Play with the semi-automatic scale modes too! You know, when a single tiny triangle remains visible after a few flicks of the mouse wheel.",
    "note": "There's one more scale to work with. I'll tell you all about it after the video.",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "documentationURL": "",
    "slider": "toBottom",
 "documentationURL": "" 
}

tutorialSteps.name: GIF
No Lock on Time Frames!
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Time Frames Salad?",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "time-frame-scale",
    "definition": "News-flash about the ->Time Frame Scale->: there is no automatic mode!",
    "paragraph1": "You may freely toggle through all available time frames! In descending order: 24, 8, 6, 4, 3, 2, and 1 hours, and 45, 40, 30, 20, 15, 10, 5, 4, 3, 2, and 1 minutes.",
    "callOut": "",
    "paragraph2": "",
    "note": "",
    "important": "Beware when you switch the time frame scale to lower time frames! Dropping time frames too fast and without adjusting the time scale may cause too much information to be rendered on-screen at a time, slowing down your computer. How much information density your hardware may handle depends on its CPU and GPU performance.",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toBottom",
 "documentationURL": "" 
}

tutorialSteps.name: GIF
Scales' Best-Kept Secrets
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Scales' Best-Kept Secrets",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "balance",
    "definition": "You just learned the basics about the three scales governing the charts, but there's more!",
    "paragraph1": "Remember I mentioned that a ->Time Machine-> may feature multiple charts from multiple exchanges and markets? There is no limit as to how you may visualize data in Superalgos, and scales play a major role in more complex configurations than the ones we are exploring at this point.",
    "callOut": "If you wish to learn all the details, feel free to go through the Scale Boxes section of the documentation.",
    "paragraph2": "",
    "note": "",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toBottom",
    "documentationURL": "https://docs.superalgos.org/suite-scale-boxes.html" 
}

tutorialSteps.name: Switching Gears
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Switching Gears...",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "layers-manager",
    "definition": "Leaving scales behind, let's take a look at how the system makes data available on the charts.",
    "paragraph1": "Every ->Timeline Chart-> has an associated ->Layers Manager->, which is represented as a drop-down menu listing multiple layers.",
    "callOut": "To open a layers manager, scroll the wheel of the mouse on its header. Use the wheel of the mouse to scroll through its content too!",
    "paragraph2": "See the video on the next step for clarity...",
    "note": "",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Right",

tutorialSteps.name: GIF
Layers on Top of Layers
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Layers on Top of Layers",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "layer",
    "definition": "Your data mining operation features bots making data products. Each product is made available on the charts through a ->Layer-> in a layers manager.",
    "paragraph1": "The first layer manager to the left of this time machine features three layers. Those layers represent the data products that the ->Trading System-> we are going to test later on uses to make trading decisions.",
    "callOut": "To turn layers on and off, left-click on them!",
    "paragraph2": "",
    "note": "Superalgos ships with many more indicator bots, but we are not using them for this tutorial. You will learn about them later!",
    "important": "",

}

The Hard Data
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "The Hard Data",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "plotter-panel",
    "definition": "A ->Plotter Panel-> features non-graphical representations of data, mostly in the form of numerical values or text.",
    "paragraph1": "Each layer may or may not feature one or more associated panels. It's up to the developer of the corresponding ->Indicator Bot-> to define them or not.",
    "callOut": "To access panels, left-click on the plotter panel icon of the layer of choice.",
    "paragraph2": "",
    "tip": "You may move layers managers and plotter panels by left-clicking on their headers and dragging them to any corner of the screen.",

tutorialSteps.name: GIF
Back in Time
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Back in Time",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "time-machine",
    "definition": "This is the ->Charting Space-> hierarchy setup of the ->Time Machine-> we've been playing with on the charts.",
    "paragraph1": "",
    "callOut": "Spend a few minutes exploring these definitions! Take a peek at different node's menus!",
    "paragraph2": "I hope the structure of nodes is intuitive enough to grasp how powerful the concept of the design space is. You set up a time machine by adding timeline charts nodes and the desired scales. Then set up layer managers and layers referencing the corresponding ->Data Mine Products-> so that the desired data becomes available on a particular layers manager on the charts. It's like the Legoland® of trading charts!",
    "tip": "",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Right",
    "slider": "toTop",
    "positionAtReferenceParent": true,

referenceParent.name: Lightning Strike Backtesting Session My Computer

tutorialSteps.name: Visual Scripting on Steroids
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Visual Scripting on Steroids",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "indicator-bot",
    "definition": "Talking about block-building, we are now in the confines of the Masters ->Data Mine->. To your left, the definition of one of the bots you sent mining minutes ago.",
    "paragraph1": "Pretty much like with the Lego-like definitions of the ->Charting Space->, bots are too defined on a visual environment.",
    "callOut": "All developers need to code is the actual ->Data Building Procedure->.",
    "paragraph2": "Everything else is defined on a visual setting: processes with their dependencies, outputs and so on, and products, with their record and dataset definitions, etc.",
    "tip": "",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Right",
    "slider": "toTop",
    "positionAtReferenceParent": true,
 "documentationURL": "" 
}

tutorialSteps.name: Plotters Magic
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "Plotters Magic!", "gif": "", "image": "plotter", "definition": "And this is how plotters are built! Plotters create graphical representations of data... from candles, to everything else!", "paragraph1": "Again, visual scripting at its best! Plotters use stylized polygons made out of coordinate points to paint lines and shapes that represent data. Every layer made available on the charts is created with a set of definitions of the sort you are looking at right now. The particular case of the Resistances and Supports bot is a rather complex one, but does showcase the power of the tool!", "callOut": "Crawl your way up the branches of the Resistance Zone 5 ->Polygon-> (to the right) for a sneak peek of how this beauty was built!", "paragraph2": "", "tip": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toTop", "positionAtReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Let's Do Some Testing!
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Let's Do Some Testing!",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "testing-environment",
    "definition": "We are back on the ->Network-> hierarchy to show you one of the core strategy-testing resources built-in the ->Trading Bot->.",
    "paragraph1": "But before you run your first ->Backtesting Session->, let's go on a quick scouting mission to grasp how the ->Testing Environment-> is set up.",
    "callOut": "Expand the testing environment and look at the structure of nodes to the right... Looks Familiar?",
    "paragraph2": "Indeed! It resembles the ->Data Mining-> section: tasks are organized by exchange, market, and trading mine, so that you may test any number of strategies optimized for different markets, on multiple exchanges.",
    "tip": "",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toTop",
    "positionAtReferenceParent": true,
 "documentationURL": "" 
}

tutorialSteps.name: Aim High, Trade Big!
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "Aim High, Trade Big!", "gif": "", "image": "network-node", "definition": "Picture an army of bots working with multiple exchanges, markets, and strategies, running on a network ala trading farm.", "paragraph1": "That is what the ->Network Node-> is about. What you've seen so far is running on your local machine. But...", "callOut": "Superalgos supports distributing tasks across networks of nodes running the backend to be processed in a coordinated fashion, enabling smart and scalable operations. Any machine running the GUI may control the enterprise!", "paragraph2": "You may set up a network with a few Raspberry Pi, an industrial-grade datacenter—or anything in between.", "tip": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toTop", "positionAtReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Enough Digressing!
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "Enough Digressing!", "gif": "", "image": "backtesting-session", "definition": "We'll run a ->Backtesting Session-> with a bunch of preconfigured parameters so that you may have a quick glimpse at how simulations work.", "paragraph1": "As you can see to the right, a trading session has a reference to a ->Trading System->. That is, the ->Trading Bot-> will apply the rules of the referenced trading system to make decisions. There's also a reference to a ->Trading Engine->—a subject worth its own chapter, so I'll leave it for later! ", "callOut": "The trading session is affected by several parameters. Take a quick look at their configurations selecting Configure on the menu!", "paragraph2": "", "tip": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toTop", "documentationURL": "", "positionAtReferenceParent": true }

tutorialSteps.name: What? When? How?
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "What? When? How?",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "parameters",
    "definition": "->Parameters-> determine key aspects of how the trading session is to run. Let's take a quick, superficial view...",
    "bulletListIntro": "",
    "bulletArray": [
        [
            "->Session Base Asset->:",
            " no capital is assigned in BTC."
        ],
        [
            "->Session Quoted Asset->:",
            " 1000 USDT of initial capital."
        ],
        [
            "->Time Range->:",
            " we'll test a single day, 2020-09-01."
        ],
        [
            "->Time Frame->:",
            " orders are placed/canceled every minute, thus 01-min is appropriate."
        ],
        [
            "->Slippage->:",
            "it's irrelevant for this case, as the trading system uses limit orders only."
        ],
        [
            "->Fee Structure->:",
            "0.1% is the lower Binance tier."
        ]
    ],
    "paragraph1": "The remaining parameters do not affect the simulation. To learn more about these ->Parameters->, take a look at the documentation.",
    "callOut": "",
    "paragraph2": "",
    "tip": "",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toTop",
    "positionAtReferenceParent": true,
    "documentationURL": "https://julian-molina.github.io/Documentation/suite-parameters.html"
}

tutorialSteps.name: Ready. Set. Go!
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "Ready. Set. Go!", "gif": "", "image": "task", "definition": "Let's get going! This is going to be quick anyway, as we are testing a single day worth of historic data.", "paragraph1": "Running a trading task is quite similar to running a data mining task. The difference lies in that—after running the task—you also need to run the trading session.", "callOut": "Select Run on the ->Task-> menu and then select Run on the ->Backtesting Session-> menu.", "paragraph2": "", "note": "When the progress notice of the ->Trading Process Instance-> get's to the 100% mark, stop the task and click Next.", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toTop", "positionAtReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Getting to the Fun Bits

referenceParent.name: Lightning Strike Backtesting Session My Computer

tutorialSteps.name: What Is It We Are Testing?
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "What Is It We Are Testing?", "gif": "", "image": "trading-system", "definition": "We've run a backtest but we haven't discussed the ->Trading System-> we are testing! Let's go through the basics!", "paragraph1": "The trading idea is buy the falling knife and sell the rebound. The strategy places a ->Limit Buy Order-> a distance below the price. If the order is not filled by the next minute, the order is canceled and a new order is placed, potentially at an adjusted rate. If the price drops suddenly, chances are the order will get filled. If that happens, then the strategy tries to sell at a higher price.", "callOut": "", "paragraph2": " ", "note": "Let's not discuss the merits of the trading idea but the implementation. This is a demo to show off the capacities of the ->Trading Bot->, not the strategy per se.", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toBottom", "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Green Silver Bullets

referenceParent.name: Lightning Strike Backtesting Session My Computer

tutorialSteps.name: Sell It Quick!
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Sell It Quick!",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "bullet-limit-sell-order",
    "definition": "I'm sure you noted there are no more limit buy orders after the order got filled. Instead, sell orders start popping up!",
    "paragraph1": "",
    "callOut": "Notice how the first ->Limit Sell Order-> is placed at 00:22 AM, the minute after the buy order filled!",
    "paragraph2": "It's the same minute Superalgos would have gotten notice from the exchange that the order got filled. The ->Trading Bot-> connects with the exchange and goes through two distinct cycles. In the first ->Cycle->, it finds out the status of existing orders. In the second, it gives new instructions.",
    "note": "",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toBottom",
    "documentationURL": ""
}

referenceParent.name: Lightning Strike Backtesting Session My Computer

tutorialSteps.name: Shall We Dig Deeper?

referenceParent.name: Lightning Strike Backtesting Session My Computer

tutorialSteps.name: Who's Keeping Score?
tutorialSteps.config:
{ "subTitle": "Who's Keeping Score?", "gif": "", "image": "layer-resistance", "definition": "Check the table below and see if you can interpret the support levels you see on the charts. ", "paragraph1": "
Rejections     Graphics     Comments
1   A faint, grey dotted line.
2     A grey block.
3     A turquoise block.
4     A yellow block.
5     A green block.
6     An orange block.
7 or more     A purple block.
", "paragraph2": "
For a new support level with one rejection, the dotted line marks the exact level on which price bounced. For further rejections, the blocks mark the rate ranges on which subsequent rejections are counted.", "note": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toBottom", "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: The Power of Data Mining
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "The Power of Data Mining", "gif": "", "image": "layer-resistance", "definition": "Why do levels jump up and down? There's something I haven't told you yet, 'cos I'm afraid it may blow your mind!", "paragraph1": "", "callOut": "The bot keeps track of all support levels alive since the start of the dataset, but only shows you the five levels closest to the current price.", "paragraph2": "Keeping track of information for the whole span of the dataset—which may count years—is the true value of data mining, and the kind of things you wouldn't be able to calculate with a function, on the fly. The ->Plotter-> associated with the ->Indicator Bot-> dynamically shows the five levels of support closest to the price because those are the relevant levels for the context.", "note": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toBottom", "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Find the Logic Challenge
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Find the Logic Challenge!",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "layer-resistance",
    "definition": "Now that you know how the indicator works, can you find the relationship between buy orders and support levels?",
    "paragraph1": "",
    "callOut": "Take some time to explore the period of time tested looking for clues on how support levels determine the rate of the ->Limit Buy Order->!",
    "paragraph2": "It's fun noticing how new levels form when price changes direction, and how an established level changes color when price bounces-off it.",
    "tip": "But the trick lies in counting levels above the order!",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toBottom",
    "documentationURL": ""
}

tutorialSteps.name: Here's How It Works
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "Here's How it Works...", "gif": "", "image": "layer-resistance", "definition": "Got it? The ->Trading Bot-> places the ->Limit Buy Order-> at the fifth support level! What's the logic behind this?", "paragraph1": "It's sort of arbitrary, but the strategy defines a falling knife as the price action capable of breaching at least four support levels and getting to the fifth during a single minute. Statistically, such events—in this time frame—produce more bounces than continuations. They may be caused by large market orders that temporarily increase the bid/ask spread in the order book.", "callOut": "Take a minute to verify that buy orders are placed at the fifth support level!", "paragraph2": "", "tip": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toBottom", "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Come Meet Someone
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Come Meet Someone!",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "execution-algorithm",
    "definition": "Sorry for dragging you away from the charts, but I wanted to introduce you to someone: the guy on the right is the one placing the buy orders!",
    "paragraph1": "We are inside the Lightning Strike ->Trading System->, within the definitions of the ->Open Stage->. In this stage, the ->Execution Algorithm-> takes over after the decision to take a position has already been made on the ->Trigger Stage->. I know you still don't know what a ->Situation-> or a ->Condition-> are, but I'd still like you to do something...",
    "callOut": "Take a few minutes to explore the nodes below the execution algorithm, check the formulas and conditions, and see what you can make of them!",
    "paragraph2": "",
    "tip": "",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toTop",
    "positionAtReferenceParent": true,
    "documentationURL": ""
}

tutorialSteps.name: Formulations
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "Formulations...", "gif": "", "image": "formula", "definition": "What you just went through is the definition of the ->Limit Buy Order-> that is placed and cancelled every minute until it gets filled.", "paragraph1": "This is the node that determines the rate of the limit order. Remember what we discussed earlier about placing the order at the rate of the fifth support level?", "callOut": "Go to the ->Formula-> attached to the ->Order Rate-> node and click Edit on the menu.", "paragraph2": "Well... that is how it's done! As you can see, the syntax is virtually self-explanatory! It involves defining the time frame, the indicator, and the indicator property involved.", "tip": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toTop", "positionAtReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: The Seller
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "The Seller", "gif": "", "image": "execution-algorithm", "definition": "We are now in the ->Close Stage->. I though it would be interesting to tell you more about execution algorithms, with another example.", "paragraph1": "An ->Execution Algorithm-> may handle multiple orders, of all types. In this case, multiple limit sell orders are defined.", "callOut": "Select Configure on the menu of the algorithm and reflect on the implications of this definition!", "paragraph2": "Both the open stage, where you define how to take a position, and the close stage, where you define how to exit, may feature multiple execution algorithms, each of them handling a certain amount of capital.", "note": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Right", "slider": "toTop", "positionAtReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Simplifying Complexity
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "Simplifying Complexity", "gif": "", "image": "trading-system", "definition": "We haven't discussed trading systems as a framework, but a feature relevant to this explanation is that they may handle multiple strategies.", "paragraph1": "Each strategy features an ->Open Stage-> and a ->Close Stage->, each with its own execution definitions. Each stage may feature multiple execution algorithms, and each algorithm may handle multiple orders.", "callOut": "Do you see the pattern? We call it granularity. ", "paragraph2": "Superalgos breaks down each issue to the minimum expression, and integrates the solutions. This is how it allows you to design, deploy, and manage both simple and the most complex trading setups you may envision.", "note": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Right", "slider": "toTop", "positionAtReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Let's Take a Peek
tutorialSteps.config:
{ "subTitle": "Let's Take a Peek...", "gif": "", "image": "limit-sell-order", "definition": "Before we leave the trading system, let's take a quick look into one of these orders and see what may be of interest.", "paragraph1": "", "callOut": "Expand Profit 0.6 and check the formula of the ->Order Rate-> node.", "paragraph2": "Let's focus on this misterious bit of the formula:
tradingEngine.current.position.exitTargetRate.value

The formula is fetching the value of the ->Exit Target Rate->, defined elsewhere. Let's not focus and what this target rate may be. Instead, let's take a look at the mechanism by which a ->Trading System-> may have access to information processed by the ->Trading Bot->. ", "note": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Right", "slider": "toTop", "positionAtReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Find the Node Challenge
tutorialSteps.config:
{ "subTitle": "Find the Node Challenge", "gif": "", "image": "trading-engine", "definition": "The ->Trading Engine-> administers the complexity entailed in automated trading by making information accessible to users and trading systems.", "paragraph1": "Rember my comments about granularity? Remember how the formula on the trading system fetched the value of the exit target rate? Here's a quick reminder:

tradingEngine.current.position.exitTargetRate.value", "callOut": "What if I told you that this string holds the path to that piece of information in the data structure of the ->Trading Engine-> hierarchy? Can you find the ->Exit Target Rate-> node? Expand the node and follow the breadcrumb trail!", "paragraph2": "", "note": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toTop", "positionAtReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Found It?
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "Found It?", "gif": "", "image": "copy-path", "definition": "This is how the ->Trading Engine-> makes every bit of information processed by the ->Trading Bot-> available to trading systems.", "paragraph1": "There is a path to every piece of data, and by knowing the path, you may access the data from within any ->Formula-> or ->Condition-> in a ->Trading Strategy->. Let's run a quick check:", "callOut": "Open the menu of the ->Exit Target Rate-> node to the left, and click Copy Node Path. Now, open a text editor and paste what you copied.", "paragraph2": "Ok! This is how formulas and conditions access the information... How about humans?", "note": "", "tip": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Right", "slider": "toTop", "pressButton": "", "positionAtReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: The Coolest Trick!

referenceParent.name: Lightning Strike Backtesting Session My Computer

tutorialSteps.name: GIF
Feedback Loops
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "Feedback Loops", "gif": "", "image": "limit-buy-order", "definition": "Lets take a look at another example to let the notion of the constant feedback loop sink in before we move on!", "paragraph1": "This is the data structure where information about limit buy orders is kept.", "callOut": "Go to the Trading Engine layers manager on the charts (the second counting from the left). Scroll down and turn on the Limit Buy Orders layer. Now swipe the mouse pointer over a few of the buy orders and check the effect on the nodes on the design space.", "paragraph2": "Can you envision the implications of having this level of control over the data managed by the trading bot?", "note": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Right", "slider": "toMiddle", "positionAtReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: GIF
Enough Chit Chat
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "Enough Chit Chat!", "gif": "", "image": "production-environment", "definition": "Ok, my friend... It's time for the real deal! Are you ready for a little ->Live Trading Session->?", "bulletListIntro": "I'll help you with the three main requirements:", "bulletArray": [ [ "Check your parameters,", " in particular, decide how much capital you wish to assign to the session." ], [ "Set up an ->Exchange Account Key->", " so that the app may access your account at the exchange." ], [ "Ensure a live data feed", ", that is, the data mining operation with the indicators required by the ->Trading System-> must be running and up to date." ] ], "paragraph1": "", "callOut": "To proceed with a ->Live Trading Session->, click Next.", "paragraph2": "", "note": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toTop", "positionAtReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Warning!
Let's Start With 20 Bucks!
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "Let's Start With 20 Bucks!", "gif": "", "image": "session-quoted-asset", "definition": "The default initialBalance is set to 20 USDT, which ensures we are above the minimum transaction amount supported by Binance.", "paragraph1": "The initialBalance is defined in the configuration of the ->Session Quoted Asset->.", "callOut": "Check that the above is the case and decide for yourself if you wish to change it.", "paragraph2": "", "note": "", "important": "Make sure you have at least 20 USDT at the exchange! The ->Trading Bot-> will place one limit order for 20 USDT, and cancel it the next minute in case it is not filled, as explained earlier.", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toTop", "positionAtReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Enjoy the Outdoors!
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Enjoy the Outdoors!",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "crypto-ecosystem",
    "definition": "I believe you haven't visited the ->Crypto Ecosystem-> hierarchy, right? This is where you configure which exchanges and markets you wish to work with...",
    "paragraph1": "... among other things, such as your accounts with those exchanges, your API keys, your assets, and so on.",
    "callOut": "Why don't you take a little walk and I'll catch up with you in the next step?",
    "paragraph2": "",
    "tip": "Just look around... enjoy the views...",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toTop",
    "positionAtReferenceParent": true,
    "documentationURL": ""
}

tutorialSteps.name: Your Keys, Your Coins!
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Your Keys, Your Coins!",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "exchange-account-key",
    "definition": "This is where you configure your ->Exchange Account Key-> for the Lightning Strike ->Live Trading Session->.",
    "paragraph1": "",
    "callOut": "Open the configuration and carefully enter the API name or label and the API secret key.",
    "paragraph2": "Delete the default text string for each parameter first, so that no foreign character gets mixed up with the keys.",
    "note": "In the future, when you get to run multiple live sessions at the same time, you will need to set up one ->Exchange Account Key-> per session. This is a requirement in most exchanges.",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toTop",
    "positionAtReferenceParent": true,
    "documentationURL": ""
}

tutorialSteps.name: Fire Up the Machine!
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "Fire Up the Machine!", "gif": "", "image": "data-mining", "definition": "Now it's time to fire up your ->Data Mining-> operation.", "paragraph1": "", "callOut": "Select Run All Exchange Data Tasks on the menu.", "paragraph2": "We'll give it a few minutes to catch up with the present time. Remember, all indicators must get to 100% before we can start trading!", "tip": "If you're getting a bit anxious, feel free to go down the ->Data Mining-> section and check the status of the process instances!", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toTop", "positionAtReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: Are We Ready Yet?
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Are We Ready Yet?",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "indicator-process-instance",
    "definition": "Resistances and Supports Multi-Period-Daily to the left is the last of the process to finish.",
    "paragraph1": "If this process is at 100%, then we are ready to go.",
    "callOut": "",
    "paragraph2": "",
    "note": "Either way, nothing catastrophic happens if you attempt to run a ->Live Trading Session-> when the required indicators are not up to date. There would be an error, and you'd be notified of the reason. So, no big deal!",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Right",
    "slider": "toTop",
    "positionAtReferenceParent": true,
    "documentationURL": ""
}

tutorialSteps.name: Let's Do this!
tutorialSteps.config: { "subTitle": "Let's Do This!", "gif": "", "image": "live-trading-session", "definition": "We've gone through the 3-point checklist and we are ready to go, so let's get on with it!", "paragraph1": "", "callOut": "Run the Lightning Strike ->Task->, and then run the Lightning Strike ->Live Trading Session-> to the right!", "paragraph2": "", "note": "Once you run the session, the trading bot may have to wait up to 60 seconds for the last indicator to finish processing. Once it does, you will see the current date and a 0% progress notice under the ->Trading Process Instance->, which will remain like that throughout the run.", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toTop", "positionAtReferenceParent": true, "documentationURL": "" }

tutorialSteps.name: GIF
Check Your Console!
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Check Your Console!",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "trading-process-instance",
    "definition": "If you don't see any errors on the ->Trading Process Instance->, chances are everything is working fine!",
    "paragraph1": "However, you may want to take a look at your console application and see if you notice anything out of the norm.",
    "callOut": "Take a look at your console app!",
    "paragraph2": "",
    "note": "You should be able to see the alternating executions of the Candles-Volumes and Resistances-And-Support indicators, with the Low-Frequency ->Trading Bot->",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toTop",
    "documentationURL": ""
}

tutorialSteps.name: GIF
Is It Working?
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Is It Working?",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "binance",
    "definition": "The unequivocal way to verify things are working fine is logging on to Binance and checking your order history for BTC/USDT.",
    "paragraph1": "",
    "callOut": "Go to Binance and take a look at what's going on!",
    "paragraph2": "",
    "note": "At any point in time, you should see one open order and a number of canceled orders pilling up in your order history, pretty much like in the video on the next step!",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toTop",
    "positionAtReferenceParent": true,
    "documentationURL": ""
}

tutorialSteps.name: GIF
Monitor the Fun Way
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "Monitoring the Fun Way!",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "bullet-limit-buy-order",
    "definition": "You thought we would let you monitor the ->Live Trading Session-> watching the ugly list of orders at the exchange? No way!",
    "paragraph1": "Superalgos produces the same kind of simulations you love for live sessions too, in realtime!",
    "callOut": "Can you see the first few buy orders on the chart?",
    "paragraph2": "",
    "note": "Notice that the ->Time Scale-> is set to automatic mode on the right-hand side to glue the current candle to the right border of the screen. The ->Rate Scale-> is automatic on both ends. Feel free to change those to your liking.",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toBottom",
    "repositionAtTimeMachineReferenceParent": true,
    "documentationURL": ""
}

referenceParent.name: Lightning Strike Live Trading Session My Computer

tutorialSteps.name: What's Next?
tutorialSteps.config:
{
    "subTitle": "What's Next?",
    "gif": "",
    "image": "bullet-info",
    "definition": "There are tons of things we haven't covered yet, I know! Just look around! So much stuff to see! It's mind-boggling.",
    "paragraph1": "I'm sure you still have tons of questions floating in your head... How do I build my own strategies? How do I measure performance? How do I build an indicator? How do I deploy a trading farm? How may I integrate with TradingView? How do I set up Telegram announcements? Don't worry! You'll get there my friend... you'll just have to do some reading!",
    "callOut": "",
    "paragraph2": "",
    "tip": "In the meantime, remember to stop your live session and data mining when you no longer need them running, and especially before closing the backend.",
    "important": "",
    "warning": "",
    "position": "Left",
    "slider": "toBottom",
    "documentationURL": ""
}

tutorialSteps.name: This Is The End
tutorialSteps.config:
{ "subTitle": "This Is The End!", "gif": "", "image": "close-stage-event", "definition": "Ok, my friend, this is the end! I hope you've enjoyed the show and that I've managed to get you hooked to Superalgos!", "paragraph1": "There's no doubt in my mind that you haven't seen anything like Superalgos before. As you may now figure, Superalgos is a vast system and keeps growing by the hour. The community behind the project has a very ambitious vision and is determined to make it a reality.

I hope we can count on your help once you start using the system! Superalgos is a community project, and we need your help to keep it open-source and free!", "callOut": "Check the documentation and ", "externalLink": [ "join the community!", "https://t.me/superalgoscommunity" ], "paragraph2": "", "tip": "", "important": "", "warning": "", "position": "Left", "slider": "toBottom", "documentationURL": "" }
